name: helianthus-atrorubens
distribution: It is found in the coastal states of  Midatlantic to Southeastern US
plus the inland states of Kentucky
wildlife-value: Flowers provide nectar to pollinators from July until the first frost. This is a larval host plant that supports Silvery Checkerspot (Chlosyne nycteis).  The Silvery Checkerspot has at least 1-2 broods in the north from June-July in the deep south and Texas, they have as many as 3-4 broods from May through September. Its seeds are favored by songbirds, ruffed grouse, quail, morning doves, and small mammals.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
flower-description: The 2  inch wide daisy-like flowers have 10-15 yellow rays surrounding a dark purple-brown disk.  There are several flowers on individual 3" pedicels. Blooms from July to October
leaf-description: Leaves are hairy and rough on top,  pubescent on the bottom. The leaf size gets noticeably smaller as the leaves reach inflorescence. Leaf pairs appear in a whorled pattern around the stem.  Petioles often have a winged appearance.
stem-description: The lower stem is quite hairy, it becomes pubescent to glabrous (smooth) as the leaf pairs reduce in size toward the upper part of the stem.
